misuse.notes: Under Harlan's direction and tutelage, Townsend and his medical-billing company, Townhall Enterprises, were taught how to file fraudulent reimbursement claims with Medicaid. Townsend, according to prosecutors, received billing spreadsheets from the participating groups. That gave him access to the names of Medicaid beneficiaries, their ID numbers, and the treatment they received. The participating groups paid Townsend a kickback for filing their phony claims, prosecutors say.  But Townsend took it a step further. In some cases, he sought reimbursement amounts that were twice to three times the size of the original fraudulent claims, investigators say.

asset.notes: Following enumerations present before veris 1.3.3 removed: asset.governance.Unknown.

confidentiality.notes: Under Harlan's direction and tutelage, Townsend and his medical-billing company, Townhall Enterprises, were taught how to file fraudulent reimbursement claims with Medicaid. Townsend, according to prosecutors, received billing spreadsheets from the participating groups. That gave him access to the names of Medicaid beneficiaries, their ID numbers, and the treatment they received. The participating groups paid Townsend a kickback for filing their phony claims, prosecutors say.  But Townsend took it a step further. In some cases, he sought reimbursement amounts that were twice to three times the size of the original fraudulent claims, investigators say.

summary: Medicaid fraud indictment links suspect to Charlotte consultant - Townhall Enterprises  A North Carolina man has been indicted on charges he used phony invoices to bilk millions of dollars out of Medicaid  in some case three times the amounts his co-conspirators thought he was getting.  Townsend, according to prosecutors, received billing spreadsheets from the participating groups. That gave him access to the names of Medicaid beneficiaries, their ID numbers, and the treatment they received.  Over a two-year period, his markup amounted to millions of dollars in Medicaid money, investigators say.
